Error Handling

In general, the SPMIDI software has very few instances where it will return an error code. One reason is because it has few dependencies on system calls, or memory allocation. This eliminates a common source of potential errors. Another reason is because the primary parser is a MIDI parser. A MIDI stream can come from any source and may be broken if the serial stream is interrupted. This can be caused by simply unplugging and plugging back in a serial cable. So the MIDI parser is designed to recover gracefully from any input errors.

The two main sources of error are badly formatted Standard MIDI Files, or programmers passing illegal parameters.

Error codes are always negative and are defined in the file "engine/spmidi.h".

If you receive a negative error code then you can get a textual description of the error by calling: 

const char *SPMUtil_GetErrorText( SPMIDI_Error errorCode );

For example, here is code to create a MIDIFile player. If a negative error is encountered, the error number and a text message is printed. 

    result = MIDIFilePlayer_Create( &player, (int) SAMPLE_RATE, image, numBytes );
    if( result < 0 )
    {
        printf("Error creating MIDI File Player = %d : %s\n", result,
            SPMUtil_GetErrorText( result ) );
        fflush(stdout);
        goto error;
    }
